text: Sababa has moved up to five star status- strictly based on their falafel.  Let me be perfectly clear, I have never had anything else here.  However, this is the best falafel in Vegas- and I have tried many.  The falafel and hummus comes in a pita pocket filled with tahini, tomatoes, pickles, cabbage, cucumbers, and lettuce.  They have an incredible green parsley hot sauce (crazy hot!) and their falafel is moist all the way through (not dry in the center like many others).  The falafels are fried to order and the sandwich is made in front of you.  Still wish they had fresh brewed iced tea, but I usually get takeout anyway.  This place is Israeli owned and about as authentic as it gets.
Clean place, friendly staff, easy to get to and the food is the best! Like to stop in weekly for lunch.
Best falafel and shawarma in Vegas. I crave Sababa regularly, especially their hot sauce. Everything is fresh and delicious.
Food good, but jerusalem grill better and closer to strip, but sababa was half the price and great salad.
I enjoy a meal here at least once per week and it's always enjoyable. I especially love the kind staff and the exceptional food that always satisfies our tastebuds.

Love this place. The falafel is not the best but it is tasty. The hummus and tahini has great flavor.  The kebab is so delicious. They have great lunch specials. I have never been disappointed and leave happy and full.

ETA: I think there has been a change in ownership or management. Went back not too long ago and was seriously disappointed. Prices are higher and food does not taste as good.

I stumbled on this out of the way place on my way to Red Rock Canyon.  What a delight. Without a doubt the best falafel sandwich I have had in years. And I am a native New Yorker who knows good falafel.  The pita pockets are unique -- spongy, fluffy and light -- and seem to just melt into the sandwich.  The falafel is fresh and just the right consistency -- not too crispy or dry.  And they will stuff the sandwich with your choice of fresh condiments.  All for $6.99, drink included.  Friendly and helpful staff just add to the fine experience. My advice is to make the effort to get to Sababa.  You won't be disappointed.

For the past several times that I've been coming to Vegas and to the Vons Shopping Center (not certain of the name) I've noticed Sababa. Actually, I never knew it was called Sababa since what really jumped out at me was the Falafel + Pita + Soda deal for $6.95. I've always had a penchant for Middle Eastern food and kept hoping we'd stop by one day since we always go to Easy Life, which is located in the same plaza.

So during this past trip, I really had a hankering for something Middle Eastern and kept hounding my sister about it. We were supposed to go to Zaytoon, a Persian eatery/market but the name and location eluded me at the moment so we came here instead. I had entered the restaurant with the aforementioned deal on my mind but once I was inside and glanced upwards at the menu I had no idea what I wanted. The owner who is Israeli and definitely loud and proud about his restaurant immediately asked if we've been here before and we told him "no". He then gave my sister and me a falafel ball topped with a dollop of houmos to try out exclaiming that it was the best in the world. I've never particularly liked falafel since it's a vegetarian item and I need my meat but I'll admit it helped whet my appetite! 

We ended up ordering the Sababa Special, which the establishment touts as the "Ultimate Pu Pu Platter." For $17.95, it came with falafel, houmos, kababs, pita bread, shawarma, and salad. It was alright and the portion seemed small at first, but I got full off it even though I had to share with my sister. We also ordered a four piece appetizer thing that came with some bourekas and other stuff. I would have liked the houmos to have been less salty and the shawarma to have been beef (they don't have lamb here) rather than chicken. 

The service was also pretty good since the workers were pretty attentive. This place is like a hybrid of sorts since it's not entirely fast food but it's also not exactly a sit-down establishment either. You need to order at the counter but you have the option of paying upfront or after you finish eating and must pay at the counter regardless. They bring the food to you and they come to you to ask if you need drink refills but there are no designated servers.

Sababa has pretty much beaten out all the other Kosher eateries out there in Vegas. And theres's a reason why...the food is fresh and delicious! It is a clean eatery, with the salad bar protected by a panel of glass and the schwarma grill on display so you know exactly what your food will look like and how it's handled. 

The portions are good for the price you pay and the service is accommodating. It is worth the 20 mile drive my husband and I make out once in a while when we know we want a good Israeli dish. My personal favorite: Beef steak plate  ($22)....very juicy and well marinated in my opinion!! 

The reason I give it 4 stars is because the food and beverages are very pricey.

When my girlfriend and I first walked in, there was nobody behind the counter, but three people were sitting at tables. One was (I assume) a customer, though he had no food. The other two people were employees. After about 20 seconds of wondering what to do and a few weird looks from them, one of them stood up and went behind the counter to help us.

As we decided on our selections, the guy behind the counter gave us two pieces of falafel to try with the hummus. It was delicious! It was also the only positive thing about this experience.

We decided to try the falafel sandwich meal that is advertised on the outside of the building. The man behind the counter grabs two pitas and slices them with a blade. He then tucks it in nicely to make a pocket for the ingredients, all of this with his BARE HANDS. My girlfriend and I looked at each other with the same realization: he never washed them from sitting at the table in the lobby on his cell phone. When I asked for hummus in my sandwich, he rudely stated that it came with it. Okay, not a great first impression. But maybe he was having a bad day, I thought. He proceeded to add ingredients to my sandwich that I did not want, and he did not ask me, though he did ask my girlfriend. Weird. He then literally threw our sandwiches in a bag, slammed the bag on the counter in front of us, gave us two drinks, and gave me the total. About $17. 

While hesitant at the thought of his unwashed hands making our sandwiches, I asked if he took American Express because it wasn't on the list of accepted cards near the register. He gave me a loud, rude "yes" right in my face that actually took me aback. He then flicked my card on the counter and threw the pen for me to sign. I don't know what was going on, but it was very weird, angry, unwelcoming vibes coming from that place. Never again.

I've seen this place every time I go to Von's for groceries.  So, I finally decided to stop in to Sababa's for some lunch to go.  When I went in, an employee greeted me and suggested I try the falafel/salad plate.  Fine, I thought - I love them both!  However, when he rang up my order, it was $11.00!!!  For lunch - 5 small falafel balls sitting in hummus, and some salad --- for lunch, no less!  I was expecting to pay around $7-8 for a lunch plate.   So, it was very over-priced for the quantity of food.  If falafel is this expensive, then how much would their meat dishes be????  Anyway, when I got back home, I ate the food.  The falafel was very salty, and tasted like it was fried in old oil.  The hummus was just ok.  The salad was very good - but overall, the place is WAY overpriced for the quantity and quality of food.  There are better Middle Eastern restaurants and deli's here in town.
nice staff. very casual. baby chicken was great. burger was excellently made. very fast food-ish

I liked the food but the customer service ruined it... Only the woman was working in the kitchen and was very courteous... Two other male employees were watching football and were jerks. There was this short fat dude with a goatee and he was an absolute jerk and did not pay any attention and was engrossed in the football game. The poor lady was all by herself. If it was not for her, I would have stormed out.

Good food and flavors owned by a nice family. Pulled tables together to accommodate us fast. Very nice and humble owners. Highly recommended to everyone. Just a bit less salt on the falafel will make them the best in LV.
The prices are high for the food they serve here. Clerk was kind of pushy and not that nice

Great service, great owner! He was packed, yet he still gave our party of 8 outstanding respect and service. He really cares about each and every customer that walks in.
Not to mention they are SO clean! Who cleans their deep fryer EVERY night? They do, they do! That's why their fries are so nice and clean, you can def tell and taste the difference. 
The food was yummy too! I have to give this restaurant 5 stars :)

The best falafel around!! I have to agree with a lot of the other yelpers on here that Sababa truly does have the best hummus in Vegas. This is one place I will definitely come back to. Oh yeah and the hot sauce should be renamed to really really hot sauce, but hey if spicy is your thing then by all means get it.

I've been to Sababa a few times for their falafel pitas - which have always been fresh and delicious. Recently however, I finally convinced my family to come along with me to try their amazing food. The sign on their door shows business hours until 3pm on Friday. We stopped by at 2:45pm and found the door locked. Someone let us in and there were quite a few people inside. My wife and her mother spent a few minutes looking at the menu (because they've never been there) and when we asked if we could order, the employee behind the register told us "That's why I'm standing here. The sooner, the better". I was a little surprised at the poor attitude, but determined to have a nice lunch. Then we're told there were no more falafels, and there wouldn't be any fries for my toddler's kid's meal because the fryer was already off. With the limited menu and the poor attitude, we decided to leave and go somewhere else since it was obvious they didn't want our business. As we drove away I told my wife it was too bad because the food is great there. My wife told me too bad because she will never go back there. 

If they want to close at 2:30pm then they should just close at 2:30...
Sababa is delicious. It was always delicious and it's just as good as it was under the old ownership

Decent Israeli restaurant here in Vegas.  Falafel were ok, a little salty for my tastes but the shawarma more than made up for it, it was delicious.  And the pita were excellent, still soft and warm.  The houmos was good to, it didn't overpower the shawarma.  To preface this, I just moved back to the states from a period of living and working in Israel, so I was kinda of disappointed that they didn't have Laffa.  Overall, a quite decent Israeli restaurant that I will come back to when the craving hits and I'm on that side of town.

What a total rip-off maybe the local suckers do not know any better I travel on business a lot eat kosher and this place is over priced small portions greasy and salty try Vegas shwarma near by or near the strip trynJerusalem grill or Haifa you will be more then pleased compared to this sub standard place .

This place has the worst and most expensive shish kabob I have ever eaten in my life. The meat tasted so bad and it was almost raw that I couldn't swallow it... not just That I had to pay $25 for a so called "plate".

Had the falafel, it was probably one of the best one I've had. All fresh ingredients, they build it right in front of you and the spicy sauce they add to it is awesome!!! Sorry no picture this time it was sooo good that it didn't have a chance to get a picture taken.

Ive been coming here off an on for years. I loved the original owners with their falafel machine. Omg their falafel pita were what dreams are made of. 

Today i wanted a falafel pita. I entered and soon found out they recently changed owners again and these guys are the best owners!! Good to know!  I told them their falafel pita will be the test. 

There is no falafel machine popping out fresh ones into the fryer. There is a guy molding them from scratch and popping them in. He assured me this is the best one ive ever had. 

It is pretty darn good! The crisp could be a little crispier but the flavor is great.

Very good food BUT super expansive for what you get!!!
For what we ordered the price was extremely high and not realistic for this type of food and restaurant.
The beef kebab was really good and the chicken very yummy. 
But again the price is not right ;)
So looks like the owner adjusted the quality of the falafel.  No longer green & undercooked to now it is brown and tasty.  Thumbs up to you guys.  I am back to eating there frequently.

Another fun day at DMV. So to kill time I went to this place because they're reviews looked good. Not very many glatt kosher places in vegas that actually taste good let alone good Israeli/jewish food. This place was great! Service is great and food is SO fresh. They have a salad bar and nothing looks like it's been sitting forever. I got the shnitzel and a red cabbage and cucumber mix salad. This place is far from where I live but it is def worth the drive.

I have passed this shop many times (right on Durango).  I finally stopped for a Falafel sandwich to go.  It was so moist with a great mix of fresh tomato, cabbage.  Absolutely the best Falafel I have tasted.  YUM!!!

Had a 2 hour break between jobs today. So, I was able to meet my hubby. We've had Greek food since we've been here. I'm a NYer and I haven't been too impressed but we thought we'd try this place. OMG it was amazing. It was much more Israeli Mediterranean than Greek. I love Gyros but I was much more in the mood for a falafel. So, this place did the trick. Everyone was nice and helpful. I'm glad we don't live to close because I wanted to try everything on the menu. I don't trust myself in places with good, affordable food.

Right now, especially with the Groupon available (which lets me afford it on my tight budget), this is a great choice for me if I want to go out with a friend or with my husband for a meal. :) 

The place is clean, the lighting is good, and the overall ambiance is nice - a lot of restaurants have annoying music playing in the background, but I like the music that they play at Sababa, and it's always quiet enough that it never disturbs my meal.

Polite and efficient waitstaff. They have forgotten bits of my orders before (like a side or my friend's hot tea order), but they're always quick and courteous about correcting it as soon as I mention the mistake.

I have lots of praise and no complaints whatsoever about the food. I LOVE their beef plate and always get that rich, creamy hummus with their delicate little fries (which are fun to dip in the hummus) for my two sides. Very satisfying. My friend has ordered a wrap of theirs as well as another dish, and she tells me that she enjoyed her food. 

I've been to Sababa twice in the last month, and I hope to be able to go again soon. I think that I might try to convince another friend from work to go with me next time.
Simply great food, that is tasty, healthy and inexpensive. Vegas doesn't have many places like this. You should go.

I was in Vegas for the week and craving some good baba ganoush - what I found at Sababa wasn't just good baba ganoush, it was AMAZING! Very flavorful, smooth and smoky due to the eggplant being wood fired. It's how all baba ganoush should be made, but many skip that crucial step. Its served with warm, thick pita bread. I recommend Sababa hands down! Don't have a picture because I happily ate it all before I even thought about a photo!

I ordered the falafel plate.  To me the salad was wilted. The pickles have been juice so long they were just pieces.  The hummus was ok without much flavor until I added hot sauce. Not a place I would recommend or come back to. I didn't find the staff helpful since I said it was my first time in.

I've tried hummus and falafel at just about every place i can find that has it and Sababa's is EASILY the best.  Well, the falafel has a competitor in a place in CA i had once, but the hummus is seriously the best of the best of the best.

Other than those, I think the only other thing I have tried is the beef kabobs... Pretty expensive, but also one of the best ever and well worth it.  

My only complaint with the place is the ordering/eating/paying system  - especially when it's busy.  That's the order - order first  at the counter (which can be a little chaotic), then go sit and eat at a table, then pay at the register.  

So the flow is a little awkward, but not enough to give it less than 5 stars for the best hummus, falafel, and kabobs, i've ever had on a consistent basis for the 4+ years we've been going there.

Genaiva (stealing) at its best. We ordered 5 meals for 5 people including two kebab dishes for $14.29 a piece. Unfortunately we were charged for 6 meals that included two kebab dishes at $19.99 a piece. We were able to get our money back for the 6th meal but the man who took our order (not sure if he's the new manager) charged us $19.99 twice. I told him that we ordered the cheaper kebab dishes but he said he tossed out his order sheet & couldn't verify it but he claims he gave us the more expensive meals & it's too bad. He then went on to say that we should know the difference between kebab dishes. Huh? 

Watch out for dishonest people who charge you for food you never ordered!

Hands down the best pita I have had.  I will be dreaming about this pita and planning when I can make it back for more.
My friend and I shared the Sababa Special Platter, which was a great way to sample so many items at once.  The falafel was quite good, but my favorite was putting a mixture of the spiced beef kabob with the hummus, "hot sauce" and salad in the pita.
Service was friendly and we were greeted with a free sample of the falafel dipped in hummus.  Our platter was plenty of food for 2 people for $17.95, which I thought was a fair price.

Very good. That's all I can say. My favorite is the falafel homous pita. Everything is fresh, and delicious.  A little pricey $6.99 for falafel homous pita with drink, but very filling and well worth it.
An hour after placing my order, was informed that they are out of the item we ordered.  Good food but the customer service is tragic.  Won't be back.

This is my go-to place for kabobs and falafel.  Also their pita is hands down one of the best I've had.  It's fresh, warm, and chewy.  When I moved to Vegas, I was worried that I would not be able to find a good kabob place, but then my friend told me that owner of the place we frequented in Boston (Rami's) opened a place in Vegas. I was so excited, and thought it had to be fate.  It just doesn't get much better than this!  I know several people commented on the price, but I don't mind paying more for quality food.

I would say that the Sababa special is enough to feed two people.  It's a great sampler if you don't know what you want.

Good Customer Service and good Falafel . IOrdered for their delivery the gentlemen on the phone was good. Delivery took about 40 Minutes which it seemed like it was alot quicker. Delivery Guy was very nice and food was kept in bag and nice and hot. Thanks Sababa for the good food and service. 2 stars only because I have had better, but they are good.

I like this restaurant because it is a good place for mixed groups of vegetarians and meat-eaters.  I had a mushroom boureka, and it was an amazing little pastry of buttery, flaky, savory goodness. The spinach boureka was also good, but I could have had about 5 of the mushroom. My husband had chicken shawarma, which he said was very tasty. The man behind the counter also gave us samples of the falafel, which I found to be flavorful without being dry in that oh-my-god-this-falafel-is-going-to-choke-me way. 

Yes, it's a bit expensive, but many of their food items take longer than the average hamburger to prepare, and I'm ok with that. Plus things like Phyllo dough aren't exactly cheap. Since I'm not going to take hours to put together something so yummy at home, I don't mind paying a bit extra when I feel like a special yet casual lunch.
Just want to say make sure you are charged the right price ,count your change ,check your portions and also get ready to be hustled for a tip ...Oh the food hit or miss top dollar for what you get ..

I wanted to try something new, something I've never tried so I decided on Israeli food so I stopped at Sababas. I can not say that this is the best falafel in town since it's the only one I've tried. but I can say that it's really good and I will stop for more!. Staff is very friendly and helpful since I was not familiar with the menu. The place was very small so it looked kind of busy. I had my food to go but next time I'm planing to eat there.

Visiting Vegas and craving some good Kosher food -  take the journey -  Sababa is excellent.

Sababa is one of several Hebrew slang words meaning "great" or "cool" and can express enthusiasm, satisfaction or assent ("sure," "no problem").   ...  Sababa Mediterranean Grill lives up to this ... the quality is excellent ... the taste is spot-on ... the staff is super friendly (even if you don't speak Hebrew) ... clean.  Yummmmmm.
Not the same since Rami sold the business. I recently had dinner at Sababa and my meal was mediocre at best.

Coming from NY, I was skeptical to find someplace, anyplace, that had at least half as decent ethnic food as back in NYC.  Someone told me about this place, and I decided to go check it out. 
 
It is a Kosher Mediterrannean restaurant.  They are observant, hence the seperate sinks for washing your hands before you eat.  It is not required, but one should be courteous.  Nuff said.

The food.  I was impressed.  The falafel was pretty good.  (Nothing will top Mamouns in NYC in my opinion, but this ran a very close second).  The schwarma was deleicious.  Warm, juicy, and fresh.  Just go ahead and get it with all the toppings.  You won't regret it.

Bourekas were ok, again, not the greatest, but I think that was because I was set on having the mushroom ones and all they had left was sesame (it was about 8:30 on a saturday, I believe they close at 9).  

All and all, it was good.  I would definitely go back.  I'm glad to see food like this showing up in the Valley.  Definitely makes me a little less homesick, for sure.

Having been a former employee here I must say that the food is of the upmost quality. The customer service aspect is always great and the maintenance of the facility is usually impeccable. Thank you Sababa for my time here. I'll be coming back for some of that shawarma when I go back to Vegas. Shoutout to Juanita who, without her, the restaurant would sink faster then the Titanic.

As a long time resident of Boston/Brookline and Rami's fab middle eastern food on Harvard St. in Coolidge Corner, I was so happy to find Rami in Las Vegas!  Now that I'm living in Los Angeles, I ALWAYS make it a point to visit Rami's Sababa restaurant here. The kababs and the Rami's Special plate is not to be missed... it has a little bit of everything and the perfect meal. The toughest ting I have to do is figure out what I want to eat when I am there.  And oh, the place is always SPOTLESS. Go there!  You'll be glad you did!

The people are nice and the place is clean but when i go out to eat i want good food for my money
I ordered pita falafel and asked for fries on the side
The pita was too hard and didn't have the quality of a good pita the falafel balls were good but not in the Israeli standards,
Any place i have been always the small side of fries is included in the price but here it is not
The place is still good i only give 2 stars and not more because of the pita was not good to my opinion

Had a misunderstanding on an order, leaving us with no food at closing. But, the owner was incredible and let us order anything we wanted for 5 people the next day. He really went out if his way to correct something that wasn't even his fault.

Like most Jewish-owned restaurants, this place is closed on Saturdays, so plan accordingly. I have tried to go here before but the early close time on Fridays (3PM) has foiled a few of my efforts as well. Worth pre-planning to get your shwarma fix.

Ordered takeout, staff was friendly, chatty, and quick.
Shwarma combo plate with salad, hommos, and falafel ($15) was two meals, and priced well when you consider that adding on the falafel is only a dollar more for 5 pieces- a la carte pricing is 2/$1. Falafel plate with hommos and salad ($10) is also an ample portion, and each plate comes with their own fresh, warm pita.

Shwarma is turkey, per the menu notes, but sliced and grilled fresh with good flavor. Falafel is crisp, hommos is creamy and topped with olive oil and parsley, and the salad is legit: fresh lettuce and cabbage, topped with tiny-chopped tomato, onion, and cucumber, and doused with a good amount of tahini dressing.There's no feta, but that probably carries over from the kosher dishes. I added some myself at home for extra oomph!

They also have burekas- small square pastries stuffed with potato, spinach, or mushroom; the latter is my favorite, highly recommend.

Side tangent: Not sure why this place hypes up falafel as healthy. As others have said, although it's vegetarian, it IS fried so calling it healthy is a bit of a stretch.

Fresh & tasty!

I've passed by this place far too many times so I decided to finally try it & glad I did. You walk in & it was great to see a grandpa figure sitting down & watching over the operation. He was a very cute old Jewish man and had a kind smile which already made me like this place. I also have to say right away it was spotless. Exceptionally clean & everything was in place. 
I decided to order a chicken kabab which came in a very delicious soft pita, filled with moist chicken, houmos, tomatoes, cucumbers, cabbage and tahini sauce. It was fresh and very filling. It is on the pricier side for a pita sandwich but in all honestly you can taste the quality items so I would definitely come back. 
It's a very casual environment with good service and fresh food. Simple & tasty!
Awesome falafel pita - even better smothered with my favorite babaganoush. Throw a little hot sauce, I'm a happy girl.
The best beef shish kabob in town. Great customer service and food! Tried the falafel and hamburger before and definitely will come back again for more.

Interested in trying an awesome Kosher place? Or some good vegetarian food?

Well, hey, hey! I absolutely dig on Sababa! Although the only thing I have ever had is the falafel sandwich. It is a pita with hummus, falafel, hot sauce and veggies (choice of lettuce, tomato, cucumber, pickles.)
They also offer Shawarma, hot dogs, cold cut sandwiches, and baklava. The baklava I tried was really good too! I believe I tried three different pieces. Yumm.
New owners. Even better. Larger portions and really tasty. I get the mixed grill platter and share. If you haven't been here in awhile, please try out with the new owners.

The food is good and reasonable.  I come here several times a year to get gift cards and it take up to 30 minutes for them to find them or contact the manager.  Today they said they were out of gift cards even though they had one advertised on the glass between the customers and the food.   How difficult is it to have gift cards and ring them up?  I just wasted my time for no reason    They could have called the manager of they were uncertain how to proceed.

I just moved here from israel and was missing some shawarma. let me tell you how disappointed I turned out being. I really feel like this place should get an F for being so dirty. the same guy that just cleaned the table went to go make me salad without washing his hands or wearing gloves! Yuccccck! Plus the menu prices and the price he charged me were totally off! Shame to call this kosher and Israeli food

I am addicted to the food here. Everything I order tastes authentic and amazing, and on Sundays they have amazing specials I can't find anywhere else. And it's kosher so I know it'll be clean. I highly recommend it. And if your a fan of sabich, you'll find it there on Sundays.

Great experience. Surprisingly relaxing music in an Israeli restaurant. 

Service = 5 stars
Time for food to come = 5 minutes 
Cleanliness = 5 stars, gloves, clean tables 
Price = very reasonable 
Food = tasty

BEST Falafel in Vegas!! 

Every falafel I try I compare them to "The Falafel Drive-in" in San Jose Ca. I grew up in San Jose and always compared Falafel's to the Drive-in and when I moved to Vegas I thought I would never eat Falafels again until I found Sababa's

I still love San Jose but Sabas does things that FDI doesn't and vis versa so I can't chose a winner but  Sababa's makes me feel like Im home!
Probably the finest falafel I've ever had, really light and fluffy. The portions are -very- generous, service friendly. Highly recommended if you're looking for a quick bite
Okay Mediterranean food in Summerlin,  kind of priced on the high side. Person helping the to go line was not friendly at all, maybe that's why I  felt they were just ok.

LOVE this place! Had my first visit here a couple of weeks ago. Went in to try the falafel pita since I am a vegetarian.When I arrived I was approached by the owner who was really warm and friendly. He is very proud of his food and told me he made the best falafel in the world. I do not disagree!! It was the best ever!! Very tasty and moist. And the hummus was great too! He spent a lot of time with me going over the other items on the menu that were meat free and what they were. Can't wait to go back for more falafel and try everything else he suggested!! you won't be sorry if you go here!!

Such a nice atmosphere. We walked in and the staff greeted us and asked if we wanted a sample.
We tried the falafel and it was very good. A lot of flavor and great texture. My daughter even liked it, and she's a big meat eater. So I ordered 2 falafel pita specials and a kabob plate with salad. 
The kabob was freshly made and it was filling.  There was a side of tahini for the salad. Everything was very good and the prices weren't too bad.
i love their Falafel balls with fresh hummus is my favorite there, sandwitch is great too! Shalom ! May God bless your business!

I would give this place zero stars if I could. We ordered a chicken pita and a beef kabob with specific instructions of everything on the side. When we received our order, the meat was cold and the pita was soggy. The beef kabob plate looked like they threw it into the styrofoam and everything was mixed together. When we called the restaurant the man on the phone said they did not understand our special instructions, instead of calling to verify, they threw the food together and sent it on its way. I tried eating the chicken pita because my daughter wouldn't touch it and the chicken was dry and hard with terrible flavor. At least the dog ate the chicken, so not all went into the trash. The beef kabob, the side of rice that I ordered extra and what I could salvage of the hummus  was put together in pitas I had on hand in order to make any type of meal for my daughter and I.

This place has really gone downhill since it changed ownership. I really want to see this place thrive but it feels a bit run down and I feel like the owners just don't care about quality and service. I've been coming here for years and now I have to convince myself to come. Yet when I eat here I get disappointed by the lack of people caring. Mediocre service and today the shawarma was tasteless. Really frustrating because I was craving a solid shawarma pita. Oh well.

Delicious food! It is a bit on the expensive side, but worth every penny! Their falafel is out of this world, as is their hummus, pita and kabobs! The owner is super friendly and always checks on us to make sure we are enjoying our meal.  Try it, you won't be disappointed!

very rude, has attitude. yelp says it closes at 3pm so I went about 2:40 just to see if I can get something to go real quick since I live minutes away from this location.  the 0.5 second I open the door this fat man with gray black hair and glasses just shut me off as if I was a trespassing.  as being a first time customer that received horrible first impression without being able to try the food. I will let all of my future clienteles who would want to try sababa.

Really terrific falafel, hummus, shawarma and kabobs!  If you like spicy, definitely try the hot sauce.  It's homemade and has a great flavor.

The owner is really friendly and accomodating.  All of the people who work there are great.

I have never seen anyone use the sink in the dining room.  I thought it was decorative!  Oh well, we usually get our food to go anyway.

I have to keep reminding myself that this place closes early on Friday (3pm, I think) and is not open on Saturdays.

This place went DOWN so I'm revising from 5 stars to 1 star. Quality of food is still OK however the plates are tiny and prices went way up ($10 for 2 baby fist sized reheated burekas with two small sides? Really??) Tiny falafel balls (90% bread and 10% cheakpeas, if that) and extremely annoying attitude of the person behind the counter. So basically no longer recommended. No wonder the place was empty despite the various deals they offer (free kid meal, sixth meal free, $5 off next $20, 12th meal free etc...) So many "deals" but really not worth it because repeat business is due to good food, fair prices, good atmosphere, and good attitude. None if these exist here any more.

The falafel and shawarma I had here are the best I have had anywhere outside of Israel.  The flavors are amazing, the sauces are just right, and the atmosphere is great.  The owner, Rami, also makes every guest feel like family.  I had dinner here three times in the week that I was in Vegas.  
I'll be back here every time I visit Vegas, and I might have to make a detour here if I am ever driving through the area or if I have a layover in the airport.

Came in for a falafel and found out new management raised
their prices from $7 to $9 and the falafel wasn't as good.
No cucumber and a very small amount of red cabbage.
Management should improve the product when they raise
prices so drastically!

Place is super clean. And the food looks and tastes very fresh. I like fresh, over the counter places, where I can build my own meal. This is that spot. Mediterranean menu. The chicken in my bowl was made to order and I added lots of fresh ingredients to it. Finished product was great. Need one of these in southern highlands!!

While I understand where the negative reviews about pricing are coming from, the food at this place is phenomenal.  I was in Vegas for my fiance's 25th birthday with a couple of her friends, and we stopped at this place on our way back to Phoenix.  They gave us a couple of samples of falafel for free; i usually do not like falafel but these were small and crispy with a tender inside - best falafel i have had in the states.

For entree, I had the Shwarma - salad- hummus plate, which came with a pita ($15).  The portion size was pretty damn big and the price was reasonable considering that its Kosher and a  big portion.  The Schwarma was good, the hummus was great, the salad was nice since I got to choose what ingredients I wanted.  I really enjoyed my meal.

However, what my fiance ordered is really what makes this spot 5*.  She got the beef "kabob" with fries and salad ($22).  While it sounds expensive, this "kabob" was kosher rib eye steak (the best kosher steak, period) marinated and grilled to perfection.  The owner asked me how the steak was and when I said it was great, he noted that "those kabobs are how I made my business."  I see why.   My grandpa is a kosher butcher in Detroit and I have had many many kosher steaks in my life, but this one had the best flavor of all.  Again, a large portion - if I had to guess, id say it was around 12-14 oz of meat.  The fries were also delicious.    I strongly suggest that you order this if you come to this place.  While 22$ seems like a lot, remember that kosher rib eye sells for about 18$/pound at a supermarket.

For dessert, they brought my fiance a piece of baklava with a candle in it for free (i told them when i ordered that it was her bday), which was a nice surprise.
Awesome. Great food for the price, which is very high quality and house made. Get the Sababa Special and share it with a friend, it's big enough to split!

Their beef shish kabob is by far the best kosher beef shish kabob in the US. It's delicious.
Their falafel and shwarma are ok.
Great falafel and shawarma. Fresh pita straight from the oven. Owner and workers are very courteous and polite. Prices are decent. We will be back again.

Sababa is a great Israeli restaurant. the shawarma is great and their falafel is best in town. the place is super clean and food is super fresh.
The only reason I gave it 3 stars and not 5 is because they are ridiculously expensive!
The small but most annoying thing about Sababa is their take out soda cups are so small ($3) with no option for a large drink. I always have to either buy two sodas or get my soda somewhere else. sounds stupid, I know, but it is a deal breaker for me when I want to get food to-go. they have free refills so when I have time to eat there its not an issue. but be prepared to spend about $20 per person for a shawarma plate and soda. 
Other than the high prices and shot size soda cups the food and service is great.
I go there once in a while. when I can afford $20 on a fast lunch.

The food is great i reAlly liked the hummus
And we had a free pita falafel for free so we really apreciate that!!i will come back!!
Went back for lunch a week ago and it was medioka. I asked if they'd changed hands and they have. I'll give it one more go but it looks like the talent moved back east.
good food just like pita plus in miami.the owner very helpful.its fast food.

Walking in on a Monday night, restaurant wasnt packed but with the people who were there, they were mostly jewish people (as per the Yamaka/Kippa and the Israeli language). Loved this fact as it told me it was authentic. 
We ordered: 

1)Falafel plate: 9.99- Large side of hummus, and babaganoush 
-BABAganoush was creamy and amazing. The falafel was not crispy and was quite squishy on the inside (not what im used to)- good flavor but still not crispy (idk why people are raving about it), Hummus was very thick (i prefer more creamy with more tahini) 
2)Chicken rotti shawarma- 14.99$- Large portion of chicken and rice with side of french fries
- A LOT OF chicken and rice- according to my husband who ate it (i dont eat chicken)- he said the chicken wasnt flavorful and was quite dry)- hefty portion of french fries
Boreka 1.99- Potato pastry (bland and kinda tasteless) 

They were out of: Moroccan cigars, Kubbeh meat, and ground beef kabobs (which is all the things I wanted to try)

Overall- A-OK. Not heavily recommended. The portion sizes are HUGE- 1 platter is def enough for 2 people or maybe even 3. 

The restaurant is clean and well kept. The owners seem nice. 
Not sure if ill be back.

This place treated me so differently, as if I didn't belong there. I spent around $50 for 2 adults and 2 kids and didn't get any quality service. The food is six out of ten, and yes kosher is healthier and more expensive, but honestly when a family comes to your resturant and you treat them like they don't exist, what's the point of going. They definitely need to change many things, and don't ask for extra anything aka pita bread because they already give you one when you get a plate. Stingy, snobby, rude, and neglectful, this place gives my people a bad name, please save yourself sometime to treat yourself elsewhere. BTW your hummus is only okay. Your falafel and kabob sizes is super small and over priced. The eggplant is very good, but expensive. Please fix and I'll change my review. Also, when I tried to use my YELP CHECK IN FREEBIE.... they didn't acknowledge it and forgot two of my orders even after they charged me for it.

This is the best falafel in Las Vegas, and I spent the summer in the Middle East so I totally feel qualified to tell you this. The owner is an intimidating macho Israeli Sabra type, though, the other reviewers do not lie.

It is, however, miles better than the other kosher falafel place.

For a hungry Israeli on his way to the airport, Sababa is a godsend. My shawrma wasn't cheap at nearly $11, but I got great value for my money. They have amba, so you know that they're the real deal, although the shrug could be spicier. All the salads were fresh and delicious, but somehow the pita held it all.

Now offer shawarma on baguette, and I'll really feel like I'm in Israel.
I'd give it five stars, but the service is less than mediocre and the it's maybe overpriced... Probably the best falafel in town though.

Food was extremely delicious and I felt so good just being in this place. 
I had Shawarma dinner and they bring out a wonderful spread of sides to add to the dish and each and every plate was absolutely perfect. 
Employees are fantastic and very friendly.  
Very authentic and truly a great experience. 
Thank you guys I will be back with the entire family soon .

Best Falafel in Las Vegas.

Sababa changed owners about the time that we arrived in Vegas direct from Jerusalem. In case you didn't know, btw, Jerusalem is THE ONLY place to have falafel the way it should be. Actually, not just anywhere in Jerusalem, but a select few places. More like 3 places in the Old City (Muslim Quarter) and 1 place in the Mahane Yehuda Shuk. Nowhere else. But I digress ...

So, Sababa's new owner, Chef Effie, is a native Jerusalemite (we call that Yerushalmi back Home). His falafel is the only falafel that I've eaten in this country (between San Francisco/Bay Area, Los Angeles/area, and New York City/area) that comes even close to being done right. And my picky 2 year old half-Israeli, half-Palestinian son will eat it nowhere else in the entire US of A. 

The hummus is also decent and it's fantastic to see it with ground beef (hummus ma lahmay in Arabic) and other Jerusalemite toppings. 

He has real laffa (laffa is originally Iraqi but now essentially a Jerusalem thing as far as anyone is concerned - it's like a pillowy lavosh) and pita from Angel Bakery. Now, I would've chosen  to collaborate with a local bakery rather than ship it in frozen, but hey, it's kosher and that's probably the main downfall in all of this for me ... although the new mashgiah  (kashrut/kosher supervisor) is super nice. 

Sababa also has pargit! Yay me! That is pretty much a chicken kabob type of thing that you put in a pita or laffa. 

There's chicken shnitzel to please the Ashkenazi palate, and malawach (like a paratha bread) and jahnun (malawach rolled up essentially - both are Yemenite specialties) on Sundays. 

There's a new kids menu, too, that'll even please American kids. Not mine, though. He can't get enough falafel (did I mention he loves the falafel, enough?).

Btw, special mention to the fact that there's Sprite Zero in the fountain drink selection! 

The two downfalls for me here are this: 1) I keep on losing the punch cards. I probably have 10-20 of them between my whole household that are hiding in some black hole somewhere. Maybe this could be done digitally by either phone number or email? Freebie from my consulting gig right there. Woops. 2) Train the staff on what the food needs to taste like and how to be slightly friendlier. They don't know how to quality check and the chef/owner can't be everywhere at once. 3) (Yeah, I said two, but oh well) It's kosher. Which means prices go up to pay the mafia - er, Kashrut certification agency, and it's closed on Saturdays. 

Still gets 5 stars in my book .. because, well, FALAFEL. Got it?

My expectations were pretty low when I saw the yellow flags (alternatively flashing "hummus" and "falafal") lining the pavement of the busy Durango stretch that fronts Sababa.  Once we walked in, we were greeted by a booming voice and a friendly smile from the guy behind the counter, and a wave from a little man, furiously wiping the table of a foursome just leaving.  The behind-the-counter dude looked at us, instantly knowing we had never been to his resto before.  "I have the best falafals in the city, my friend" he told my man, as he handed him the perfect piece of falafal -- crunchy on the outside, but a moist inside with the perfect blend of spices.  Sababa's hummus is also a treat -- nice consistency, and not too tangy.  Yum. Sababa was a great find (once you get passed the yellow flags) on a side of town I don't frequent often.  Highly recommend it!

Me & my husband's first time trying Sababa and we are so happy that this will be our new place for date night. Wonderful service and great food. Thank you so much for helping us with the menu and making our sunday beautiful!!

Ate last night and was greeted by an abrupt and annoying middle eastern man that seemed to mean well, but wouldn't leave me alone as a studied the vast selection of dishes.  If I had to guess, he's probably Israeli, and these people have an abrupt way about them -fine, no prob.
I eventually just told them what I was looking for, and they suggested some sort of chicken plate.  I also had a snapple, and given this is basically a falafel stand, I was pretty surprised to be charged $22 for what I had ordered.   Given the food was mediocre AT BEST, and given it was served in a foam container in a fast food enviroment, I was dissapointed on the value front.  I've had WAY better middle eastern food at a fraction of the cost whether it be Lebanese, Persion or Afgan..
Anyway, the part that really ruined the meal for me what fact that the other very kind (non-middle eastern) gentlemen who served me actually handled my pita with his bare hands, and he had two old, worn dirty band-aids on each of his thumbs which certainly came in contact wtih my food.  Absolutely disgusting, and totally lacking in any sort of basic food-service hygene.  
The original guy was so annoying I didn't even bother bringing up the issue, I just tossed the pita bread in the trash when I got home and wondered how much food this guy touches with his dirty band-aid hands.
All in all, $22 for a crap experience.

Best Falafel pita sandwich I've found since being in Israel.  And they have a great assortment of extras to add to the sandwich (I like pickles and hots along with cucumber, tahini, etc.)
The pita bread is softer and a bit thicker than other places -- love it!  Tasty babaganoush and hummus w/beef too. Service was very good.  The atmosphere is nothing special, but it is clean and the food will keep us coming back often although we live on the other side of town!

My family and I had dinner at Sababa this weekend and the food there is absolutely delicious. One of my favorite dishes is the schnitzel plate with rice. Since it's Kosher food it makes it not just tastes great but also healthier. The owner Effi does a wonderful job running the place.

I'm a sucker for shawarma and you really have to be one to enjoy this place. I get that the owner is in a location and makes a product where he CAN charge that much, but that doesn't mean you have to. The good thing is that you pay after you eat, so you get to have a date with some shawarma before you get _____ in the _____.   

Seriously though, the food was delicious. I rocked the shawarma houmos salad plate, which is pretty self-explanatory. The shawarma was spiced, moist and had that crust that I love. Note: it's turkey meat. The houmos was also excellent. The kind of 'mos that you end up dipping everything in. 

The place itself has about a dozen tables and looks like every other take out joint in town. There's a TV on the wall if you are rolling solo. 

Again, the -1 star here is for price and because it says 'healthy falafels' on the wall, which is a pet peeve of mine (deep fried = not healthy). I'll be back, regrettably, bc sometimes it's OK to get your ______  ____ed for some decent shawarma.

I went in with my husband for lunch yesterday and the food was super delicious! I'm super picky when it comes to Israeli food and I now feel like I finally found a good quality Israeli food restaurant in this town! I literally tried them all and wasn't very impressed! Reading other reviews about this place for costumers complaining about the price well let me say it is well worth it and you can definitely taste the quality! 
I ordered the cuscus with vegetables and shawarma and hubby got shawarma in lafa and side of gulash all was fresh and taste just how real Israeli food should be! The owner made sure we were happy and include lots of small salads and extras! 
I will definitely be back to eat at Sababa at least once a week! Great experience!
Yummy food, clean restaurant, nice atmosphere! The beef kabob and falafel are very good. Prices are reasonable.  Recommend coming here for some authentic and delicious Israeli food!

We have been here many times on our visit to Las Vegas. 
This time we celebrated a Bar Mitzvah with 20 people. 
The food was amazing as always, and we had service with a smile..
Hoping to celebrate many more trips and occasions..

We loved eating here.  The staff was super helpful assisting us with our order.  I'm a vegetarian and my boyfriend eats only meat so we are totally challenged in where we are going to dine.  This place was perfect.  Awesome falafel!!!  The staff even gave my boyfriend a falafel sample to draw him since he is frightened of healthy food.  And guess what? He found out it was awesome.  Thanks Sababa's!

Excellent falafel. 
Very good shwarma.
Decent hummus.
Pita is so-so.
They have an awesome hotsauce.

The best thing on the menu in my opinion is the steak kabab though it's also the most expensive.

Observes sabbath and Jewish holidays.

This was a good experience, specially following other, not so good ones.
Out of all kosher restaurants in vegas, this one was good, fresh and clean. Recommended!

You "matza" try their food! Yeah I'll be frequenting this place. Gotta do a falafel comparison too. What I did consume with satisfaction is their matza ball soup. Perfect broth; comfy soup. 

Suggestion... Fava & egg hummus needs 2 pita breads. I had only ordered with one and felt stuck as to how much hummus I had left to eat without any more pita.

They were out of the regular baklava triangular shape, but I got to try another type of smaller pieces, which were just as yummy. My ever so fave is the grape juice they sell.

It's a clean restaurant with friendly service, and their food is good. Menu is good too. Quality and pricing is average. They have indoor and outdoor seating.  The beverages they sell have a good variety; will try one of their sodas next time.  Will keep ya' posted.
Unbelievable Shish Kebab. Great Prices. Best Pitas in Town. Very Quick Service. Excellent Shwarma. New Ownership Is Doing a Fantastic Job. Will come back.

Probably one of the best Shawarmas Ive ever had. Perfectly cooked slow roasted chicken from the spit (slightly crispy roasted on the outside and juicely tender grilled on the inside). Topped with fresh tahini, pickled turnips, and non-sandy tasting hummas. Definitely can taste the perfection of the chicken here that I havent found anywhere else thus far... wonder if its the kosherness? \_(?)_/
Great food, great people friendly, clean place. The owner was a nice guy he chit chat with us, and he is passion it about his restaurant.

This is my favorite Middle Eastern place! I live in LA and always get my chow here when I am in Vegas. The owner used to own Rami's (his name) in Brookline, MA and I missed him when he moved but since I live on the west coast now, I go there all the time. It's consistent and delicious! Go there!

Wanted to try this place as drive by it often and in my hood. No great shakes for me.

Ordered the chix schnitzel and beef kabob plate. The beef kabob itself was very tasty but small in portion. Think 4 kabob pieces the size of mini hot dogs. One star taken off straight away as the cost is 15$. The salad was floating in dressing and overpowered by the canned chickpeas and old tasting pickles. Hummus is decent.

Chix schnitzel was extremely tasteless. Plate is 16$. In both cases, completely overpriced. Pita was okay but nothing memorable.

I will not be returning.

Fantastic middle eastern food, excellent for lunch or dinner.

I have only one critique, but it is a notable one.

When you come into the restaurant, unless money is no object, order directly from the menu.

If you come in with 4 or more people, a lot of times the (very nice) staff will offer to just make you a dinner for 4 with a little of everything. They are so nice, and it sounds like a good way to decide what to eat.

The problem is two-fold. One, you many times are still a little hungry and there isn't much to take home. And two, when they give you the bill for your little "dinner for 4" you will pass out from the price.

Unfortunately we had this happen 3 times with parties of 4 to 9 people before we learned our lesson. And they tend to get a little hostile when you object.

So just remember, order directly from the menu and you'll enjoy a delicious meal without any sticker shock.

Fresh and tasty. Discovered it has new owners who have a very high standards. Have made a few special trips and will for sure stop when I am in the area. Even if I'm not hungry, I get something to go for later.

Good food in a bright, airy space.  We tried a salad plate with various mezze as well as a chicken shawarma.  Flavors were good and portions were large.  Ordered a fountain coke and wanted a refill but none offered. Servers were friendly.

I've tried a lot of falafel sandwiches and you can't beat this one! The pita bread is so soft and fluffy. The falafel has the perfect texture crunchy outside and soft inside. A generous stuffing of humus, vegetables, Tahini and spicy sauce.

I love this place, I loooove Israeli food but sometimes the meat is dry. Best falafel in town makes up for it. A bit pricey but the portions are great. 

I always forget that they close early on Friday's for Shabbat and I find myself sometimes jonesing for a good hangover meal on Friday or Saturday :\

Food was underwhelming...pita bread was good and hummus wasn't bad, the beef kabobs lack flavor, just plain burger meat in shape of a hot dog and the rice was bland. They were out of over half of their menu. Overall, not worth a trip.
I always order the falafel, over filled with fresh veggies and it's amazing tasting hummus. I crave it all the time, this place makes the best!

Awful experience! Rude man behind counter. Chicken was undercooked and asked for a new dish and he acted very unapologetic and annoyed. Will never come back. Nothing fancy...like a subway for Mediterranean food. Over priced crappy food and terrible customer service.
If you want a great falafel pita sandwich I recommend this place! The hummus and shawarma are great too.

Bad customer service, would not recommend the food here . Not kosher anymore . Ever chance owner change service and food become low and quality of the food became cheap. Better options available elsewhere in Las Vegas.
The food here is pretty good. Only downside is that its expensive! Thats kind of expected though for kosher food in las vegas. Id give it more stars if it wasnt so pricey.
Clean, cantina style restaurant.  Very reasonable prices, excellent flavours and generous portions.

I really craved a falafel so I made a deal with the devil and went here again. Big mistake! The bearded hobo looking dude behind the counter behaves like someone just mutilated his beloved cat five minutes ago. Everything's overpriced up the wazoo. I'm convinced they'd do much more in net profit if they lowered prices and increased VOLUME. At Subway or Capriotti's or any other sandwich shop I can have huge sandwiches for $6-7. At this place a tiny falafel will run you at least $11. To get full you need to have at least two. The whole time you will be eating under hostile stare of "the hobo". Enjoy ;)
They charge $20 for delivery on top of whatever your food cost. I live 3 miles away. ripoff

Me and my wife eat here every Sunday now. Very clean, great food and fairly priced. The ambiance is nice and the staff very nice and inviting. I buy my hummus here because it taste fantastic! I would highly recommend it as a healthy and flavorful alternative to fast food.

Very clean place!!!! Friendly staff! Food is amazing here! The falafel is the best I've ever had! Def worth the drive and u will leave here feeling happy and refreshed from eating such great food:) 5 stars all the way!!!!!! Kosher is the way!

I got pretty much exactly what I expected when I hit up Sababa for the first time with my Groupon.  They were overstaffed and I felt like I was at a used car dealership and not a restaurant.  Without really having a chance to review the menu, they were telling me what I should get.  Who am I to argue, though, so I got their mixed platter.  Pretty much everything they make is on the platter, and it was all really good.  But the entire meal, I kind of felt like I was being watched by the staff.  In their defense, they just wanted me to like it.  But instead, it made me think, hmm, not sure I'll be back here before they do a Groupon deal again...

This has taken over as my Favorite Mediterranean restaurant. The atmosphere is fast food ( tables and chairs) but the FOOD is Authentic. If you speak Hebrew you will feel at home. They will deliver Shabbat dinner to your home or hotel. The Hummus with Shawarma if more than enough for 2 if not 3 people. Will be back at least twice a month. They also do catering!

Consistently..I'll repeat..consistently one of the best meals I've had..consistency is one the most important concepts, because i find it difficult to find no matter what the food genre.
My favorites are the baby chicken & hanger steak...Both are superbly seasonsed & juicy...

This place has the best falafel sandwich in America.  The pita bread is great. The hot sauce is spicy and flavorful.  The veggies are crisp and fresh. The hummas is creamy and flavorful.  And finally, the pickles are amazing.

As a traveler who has had the pleasure of eating good food in many cities and countries around the globe I have to say this is one of the best places I have had the pleasure of eating. 

The food is extremely fresh and wonderfully flavorful. Rami is a gracious host and clearly has a passion for his food. I had a family style lunch with 4 people in which Rami brought a salad, falafel, hummus, pita, chicken, steak and 2 sodas. 

Lunch was beyond good...so much so I tried to eat the plate. Now I will say the meal was pricey $23/person but the fact that Sababa is Glatt Kosher (glatt technically means the lungs of the kosher and kosher-slaughtered animal were smooth) which might account for the higher than average cost.

One thing I will say the food is nothing in the range of average it is absolutely divine :) I highly recommend eating here.

I'm actually still upset.

When I first got to Las Vegas, I found this restaurant & was happily shocked as to how authentic the food was on my first visit. I know good Israeli food, plus I'm a foodie.

The second visit it wasn't as good, so I didn't go back, plus it is really expensive.

Fast forward to last Thursday & I decided to treat myself & hope that the third time was going to be as great as the first time. I also decided to take a friend there who isn't Jewish & has never had Israeli food.

At first I was like, "oh no" when I saw they were under New Management, but I held out hope.

I was SHOCKED at how bad the food was. I ordered a split plate of the eggplant & Matbucha salad. The eggplant had no flavor & while the Matbucha was slightly better, it was just spicy, it had no real flavor. I've had Matbucha numerous times in my life, so this isn't a first for me.

Their Moroccan cigars also didn't have that cigar taste I love & all I tasted was spice.

Their humous wasn't as good as the other owner's & I REALLY loved their humous, & my chicken pita sandwich was bland & the chicken didn't look to be cooked thoroughly.

The free pita chips were so hard & tasteless I took one bite & put it down.

Even the second visit when the old owner was there was better than this experience.

I didn't pay attention to the subpar customer service because the food was more important to me & Israelis aren't known for their customer service.

The restaurant was empty except for one other person. We came at around 2 pm, but still, if the food is fabulous, it should be fairly busy at 2 pm.

I guess I won't be going there ever again :  (

Had the chicken shawarma with hummous, falafel and salad - everything was excellent.

Came with a big, soft piece of pita bread which was also amazing - most pita you get tends to be hard and thin, but this was soft and fluffy and great.

Outstanding!!!!!  This is what 40 years experience does. Very good customer service, the pita bread is wonderful.

We gave Yelp a try on this, never been here but the reviews look good. Well, one again Yelp came through. Great food. 

Try the green hot sauce with some of the humus.  Great mix of flavors.

Chicken shrawma plate is very tasty. The humus is the best humus I have had anywhere. I am constantly ordering humus at other restaurants now to compare with Sababa's humus but none come close. I like their style of pita there too. The only complaint and reason I did not give them five star rating is their price is a little steep for what you get. I think if they lowered their price a little, more people would eat there more consistently. I know I would go back more frequent if they lowered their price

No doubt the BEST falafel in Vegas!

Not sure why some of you out there are haters, but maybe you should try it again.  Everyone I have even taken there has been really satisfied with their meal.

This place has phenomenal falafel, truly the BEST I have ever had (by the way, I am not from Vegas but moved here for a short 1 year stint from LA... so I have had plenty of falafel in my time)...

Its Kosher, so no milk products of any kind, but some cool Israeli soda drinks available and the made-to-order falafel is awesome, hummus heavenly and pita is really, really light and delish!!  The hotsauce is some heavely spicy green thing that is on fire, the extras on the sandwich are great!  Shawarma - YUMMY.  Hummus - mmmm, mmmm good!

OK - I am not Kosher (with a name like Kristin, hard to believe, I know but I think this place is awesome.  Almost makes me want to be Kosher, so I could justify eating here daily...  

Super fresh food, clean, quick.  The guys behind the counter a friendly.  Big ups for this place.

Only draw back, closed Saturdays (which is when I tend to have my falafel cravings) and all Jewish holidays...

I came here years ago on a whim driving by and was kinda excited to find this place again after moving to this side of town.

It is a Kosher restaurant so the hours are not what we are used to in our normal daily Vegas, however the food is worth the wait and the drive.  Kosher is a BIG meaning and covers a lot of knowledge. I will not begin to explain but a bit of reading on the subject wouldn't hurt.

The food here is amazing, I remember asking my Man if we could drive the 30 minutes to go get the "Shawarma" no go.  So when we moved in this direction and I found it again it has kinda become my cheat day, not that is is bad for you but OH So Good!  I believe the Shawarma combo is the best for me I love the long roasted meat shaved into your sandwich.  I also really love the falafels buy a couple for 50cent a piece with a bit of Tahini, amazing fried goodness!  

The service is not really quick everything takes a bit to cook (because it is Kosher) and the prices are bit high, but most really great places like this are and there is a reason.  The reasons are prep, time, seasons and accountability.  I feel the safest place to eat in the world is here because they take it so serious.  

So the portions are huge that makes up for the price, the price isn't bad I thought... The meat is moist and delicious and plenty of sauce and veggies to make it all rhyme.  ask for the hot sauce but if you are weary about it ask for it on the side I ask for it lightly and I like heat if that says anything! LOL

The falafel here is good.  The guy who served me did not wear gloves to prep my good which grossed me out a bit but the hummus was good and falafel fresh so yeah. I guess just try not to think about it because I'm sure this happens more than not...

I have to give this a low rating, The owner Has another Restaurant in Mass. and is doing alright, Partly because he has the quick to the Strip locations, and yes Religios Jews DO come to Conventions....but, The Shwarma is put on his Greasy Black Griill, and he is almost as goos as Copperfield with his Magic, we had a party of 6 with 2 kid's, he will tell you he gonna make you a little this a little that and some Pita and Salad, with canned soda we were presented with a 180.00$ check!!, all but the couple that knew him from Boston got HOT, we actually got him down to 140.00 bucks, but c'mon...God is watching ALL of us Romy!!

One word. SALTY! They seriously  need to watch the amount of salt they put in their food.

I ordered the shawarma in pita and I've never had such a salty meal before. I've lived in the middle-east (Bahrain) my entire life and shawarma's don't taste this salty or are so over priced in that part of the world.

If you're looking for authentic its definitely not here.
$14 for this is just wrong, thought I was getting a chicken salad bowl like every other Mediterranean restaurant I've ever been. Feel robbed

Came here at lunchtime...but since I hadn't rolled my dissolute ass out of bed more than two hours prior, it was really breakfast. What do you order at a Middle Eastern joint for breakfast? I had the falafel pita and a cup of black tar sludge, aka Turkish coffee. It was GREAT! 
The falafel pita was jam-PACKED with all kinds of chopped up veggie stuff and was truly delish. The sludge was thick and tarry, just the way I like it.
The staff was friendly and downright jovial, and the facilities were clean and pleasant. The atmo was somewhere between the typical suburban Vegas strip mall aesthetic and a Tel Aviv Starbucks: bleached blonde JAP on her BlackBerry in the front, Hasid on his MacBook Pro at the table in the back, Israeli snacks and Mentos for sale on the counter, good times all around.
I will DEFINITELY return to this place for lunch/breakfast/whatever...dinner maybe not so much, since the menu WAS kinda pricey.

By far the worst place for service. We spent an hour waiting until we finally got our food. Under New Management is by far the worst management I've ever seen. Food was mediocre at best. Better to keep driving!

Great quality. Quick service. Fron the  shawarma to the falafel with tahini, the food is fresh and wholesome. If you like it spicy, ask fir the habanero sauce. It was busy for lunch. I would recommend highly.

First time trying Isreali did and was not disappointed.  The Shawarma was amazing.  I ordered the combination salad plate,  with the falafel and houmos. Excellent choice.  Food had great flavor. Will be back for more.

I liked that as soon as we walk in there, we hear all the employees yelling at each other in their native tongue (Israeli?). 

The falafel was good. But I don't get how people say its supposed to be healthy. Yeah, its just a wad of veggies, but its deep fried, man. Anyways, it was tasty. I got a falafel salad plate. The salad was like typical mediterranean salad (cucumbers, tomato, whatever), but the iceberg lettuce was kinda wilted in the middle of the day. The dressing was good, though. 

Even though people were yelling at each other, I'm sure it was with the lovingest of words. The joint seemed to be run by a family. And I like that.

This restaurant has AMAZING kosher food!! The meat is fantastic... I recommend this restaurant.. Their baby chicken Shawarma is my favorite.. It's really tender.. Their falafel is literally the best I've ever tried. It's a must, you won't regret it

I have been coming here on and off for years and through three different owners, and this place has managed to always maintain its quality. I always order the same thing, so my review will be narrow, but the place is definitely worth exploring. Their falafel pita is great; the falafel are made to order and don't just sit there like some other places, and its seasoning is delicious. The pita is packed with sliced cucumbers, tomatoes, cabbage and other pickled veggies. The white sauce they use is light and not overpowering. Overall a great falafel.
P.S. They close Friday at 3pm and Saturday all day in observance of the Sabbath.

The falafel is really really good! The hummus wasn't the best I've ever had and the pita was extremely dry. And it's really expensive! I spent damn near 45 dollars for two plates and a drink. I don't think I will be going back just because of the price.

We were hosting some family from Israel who were taking us out for dinner, but it had to be Kosher.  I chose Sababa after reading some Yelp reviews, and it looked like it would fit the bill.

The positives:  Good service, along with a bit of sarcastic New York Jewish Waiter-style joking from one of the waiters, who was neither from NY nor old enough to be one or even remember what they were like.  

Also positive:  Good food.  The two husbands ordered the Sababa Special platter, which included 5 small falafel, some beef kebab, chicken, rice, and a side salad.  I claimed one of Herb's falafel as my own, and thought it was close the best I've ever had. We wifeys had the Chicken Shawarma plate.  I'm used to shawarma being turkey, but it's chicken here, and it was very tasty.  We got less salad, served on the plate.

The negatives:  There is no atmosphere whatsoever.  It's set up the same way as a deli, with a long, high counter on one side, behind which the food is prepared, tables on the other side, and 4" tiles on the walls.

No wine or beer, though I suppose you can BYO.  But the bright lights aren't conducive to a wine-fueled romantic dinner.  Fountain drinks are included with the platters.  I never drink soda, but I did here.

It's pricey, but that's the downside of eating at a Kosher restaurant, and was to be expected.  My chicken platter was, I think, 14.99.  While not outrageous, for that amount I can have dinner at the Kebab House and take home enough food for a whole 'nother dinner.  

If you have to go Kosher, Sababa fits the bill.  If you don't, food that's as good or better - with much nicer atmosphere, might be a wiser choice.  Unless YOU think you look good under fluorescent light.

The hubby and I shared the Sababa combo platter (~$18). It has 2 pita breads, hummus, falafal, turkey shawerma (yeah I know unusual, right?), and beef kabobs all preceded by a medium-largish size salad.  We also ordered fries.  The salad was good, they make it to order with the ingredients on the cold bar and with tahini dressing, yum!  turkey shawerma--interesting; It wasn't dry but I guess I prefer the beef/lamb type.  hummus--tasty; nothing out of the ordinary. pita bread--not the greatest; I don't think they make it there, it wasn't warm. falafal--really good (def. order these) crunchy on the outside soft and flavorful in the inside. beef kabobs--these were the best item on the combo; juicy, flavorful, but too small.  I wanted more! Fries--standard; came frozen from a bag.  The thing that irked us was their hours.  They are really inconvenient.  I understand that the owner must be a devout Jew to close at 3pm on Fridays and all day Saturdays.
Mmmm! Favorite place in town for shawarrrrrrma!!!!!! Great food, and even better staff!!!! You guys are the BEST!!!!

This place has the best pita sandwhiches i have ever had.  Their pickles and hot sauce are my favorite ingredients.  The only thing that sucks is I typically want to go on Saturday and they are not open.

There food is always really tasty, fresh & very filling. Go when you are hungry.  The first time I went I went with my Israeli friend because I had no idea what the food was,or what to order. The owners are normally there & you will hear them speaking in their native language..kind of intimidating at first, but I love hearing languages other than English & my friend is fluent in Hebrew so I find it cool. The restaurant has a homey, relaxing feel to it.  I usually get their filafal , but next time, due to the pics here in yelp, I will expand on my food choice. All their food is super fresh. ((Kosher)) love this place :)

Best falafel EVER! Friendly staff, too.
We stopped here on a whim after a hike at Red Rocks. Our decision was between VONS' sandwiches (which are very good - good bread) or random falafels. Boy, were we glad we shoes Sababa! It was fantastic. And when the guy (the owner or manager) realized we wanted them "to go", he seemed truly disappointed, "awww, stay awhile" he said. Made us feel very welcome. Plus he gave us some falafel and hummus to sample while we waited for our food to be prepared fresh.

Had lunch and dinner here over a couple of days. 

The food is typical middle eastern. I was shocked to taste mint in the schug, but it was a refreshing change for the dishes. 

I'd ore any of the kebabs or skewers but would stay away from the soups and Schwarzwald. 

This was w best place I dine at in Vegas so I'll definitely be coming back. 

There is ample parking but the location is a little hard to find as its in the corner of a power mall with the Vons.

Came in with a large group of 8 kids and 5 grown ups!

I have to be honest it was my favorite and best experience I ever had since I moved here 4 Years ago.

The baguette was amazing with shawarma! 

The kids had a blast and Service was great!

Thank I sababa

Worst customer service!!!! Food is just as bad!!! Ordered a falafel pita and a chicken breast pita from their lunch specials menu ($6). First, they overcharged me for the chicken breast pita; they tried to charge full price instead of the $6 special price. I told the gentleman working behind the counter, who was too caught up in a personal phone call to even listen to me, that he was over charging me, that the chicken breast pita is part of the lunch special. He told me I was wrong, that only the falafel pita is on the special and he also told me I needed to prove his own price to him. 
He then came back to tell me that he would go ahead and charge me $6.99, I replied that their specials are $6. He brushed off my comment and rang up the order for $13 and some change, I checked my bank account and he over charged me by $3. I am pissed and when i called to confront them they hung up on me. Do not recommend ever going back here

their food is like crack.  I find myself craving it.  However their prices are also like crack.  Don't do crack, stay in school.

You can't go wrong with their baby chicken plate.  I like dark.

Note: This review is based on a visit that happened some time ago, before I was active on Yelp.  So although this is not based on a recent experience, it was still an experience that made me not want to give this place a second chance.

A friend and I visited this place in hopes of trying some good food we've never had before.  We're open to try just about anything.  Unfortunately during our visit, we were never really given the chance to try their food.  Upon entering we see a menu with lots of food items that we had never been introduced to at that time.  We let people go ahead of us in line to give ourselves a chance to scan the menu for things we wanted to try.  After a making our decisions we stepped forward and placed our orders.  

At least, we think we did.  We looked at one of the workers in the eyes and told him what we wanted, and he acknowledged us; maybe not the food we ordered, but he acknowledged the fact that we were talking to him.  My friend and I shrug and continue moving forward in the line and get ready to pay.  Now for some reason, we became completely invisible to the employees.  We tried to see how much our meal was, tell them what we ordered, etc.  We were flat out ignored while the people in front of and behind us continued with their business, ordering food and then paying for it.  The two of us stood around confused and tried to get someone's attention to confirm that our order had been placed.  No such luck.  

After getting frustrated with the customer service, a customer comes up to my friend and asks if his drink contains milk (we had stopped by It's A Grind and he had a frozen coffee drink).  We confirmed that milk was an ingredient, and the customer asked us to leave and finish the drink outside due to the restaurant being a kosher establishment.

Having spent the time waiting in line, ordering, waiting to pay, being completely ignored and then being asked to leave by another customer, my friend and I left out of frustration.  This is the only time I've left an establishment frustrated and disappointed without even experiencing the services/food that they offer.

This is a small place with I think less than ten tables. The food was decent but the grilled and seasoned meats were a bit salty. Otherwise, everything else in our order was pretty good, just not great. Service was also pleasant and the atmosphere relaxed. It's a pretty good place for a quick bite without any hassles.

The guy cooking in front also took our order and seemed like we weren't wanted there, like we were bothering him. He was really unfriendly. The food was ok, nothing special. The chicken was dry and old, maybe left overs from yesterday and many of the items were not available. Maybe they wanted to get rid of the old stuff first. The schnitzel was thin. I would not come back to this place.

Wonder in they have new owners? All new people up front today. Forgot to make my sandwich, when I asked about it, the guy say'"my bad", "do you want me to make it now?" What a stupid question, of course I want you to make it now! By the time I got it it was wrong and totally tasteless, don't know how he managed that! Not sure I'll be back again as this place isn't close to me, but I've always enjoyed it. On the look out for a new place now!

I absolutely LOVE this place! It is close to my nail salon otherwise I probably never would have located it. I have been here for lunch 3-4 times and the service is always very quick and the food is made fresh. 

Make sure you try the shawarma if you have never had it before, its absolutely amazing and you will become hooked at first bite! It is kind of pricey $10-$15 a person, so if you are on a $5 footlong budget, you may be sticker shocked...  But the quality is great!

Apparently what everyone eats there is the falafel. I'll have to try that next time. Baba ganoush was good. Pita was hot from oven. Eggplant in PHOTO was sliced, in a bowl, with what looked like tomatoes. Came flat, black and ugly on a plate. Might never go there again.
