Customer service was horrible. Walked in waited to place my order and waited 5 minutes just to be acknowledged. I was the only person in line! That's a long time to be greeted and have your order taken. I was very close to walking out. Food was just okay. Giving it two stars because the customer service and the price for a wrap was $12.99! Add a drink and my order came out to $16 and some change. Very pricey for just a lunch spot. Last time I'm going there!

Our table of 10 ordered a variety of things from the menu and everybody was really happy. The hummus was outstanding, the shawarma delicious and the service and atmosphere wonderful. And Kosher too!  You'll enjoy it.

Sababa is a kosher, mediteranean cafe that has the yummiest falafel. Make sure you get it with the hot sauce because its sooo dang good. Unfortunately for me, they are closed on the sabbath and they are only open till 9pm.

Typical Israeli restaurant even the owner lol. I am Israeli so you feel like you are back home. The falafel is great and the pita was full. The price was right for the falafel even if you never had it and want to try it for $6.99 with a drink. They even have a machine that spits the falafel into the fryer......I wish I had that at home. The owner was cool and funny. If you aren't Israeli you might take that the wrong way. I will for sure come back.

Best Pita sandwiches in Vegas by a mile.  Best falafel in Vegas, by a mile.  Try the kebab, schnitzel, or chicken schwarma pitas.  All fantastic.  Humus is tasty and high quality.

Main thing about this place is QUALITY.  The food looks and tastes like it's fresh and well prepared.  Super clean place.  You won't ever see these guys have any issues with cleanliness.  Veggies in their pitas are bright, crunchy, and flavorful.  Basically, they run a really, really good restaurant.  It can be pricey but that's life in the fast lane.  Don't expect cheap eats.  It's quality here.

This place was sooo good! We received the best service I've ever had at an Israeli owned restaurant, the portions were huge, and the food was delicious! I also liked that they had a soda fountain with free refills instead of having to spend $3 on a can of soda. Everyone in our party raved about how delicious the food was. I would definitely go back if/when I go back to Las Vegas.

I had a pretty strange experience at Sababa.  A friend and I arrived around 2pm, so it was after the lunch crowd was gone.  There was one woman eating on a table and there was just one guy running the place (at least that was visible) and he was in front of the counter.

He was a nice guy and gave us each a sample falafel to try.  It was good and we ordered our food.  The food was mediocre and I was really surprised to see that my part of the bill was $17!

I found the place to be overpriced and a little on the bland side.  It made me a little nervous that there was only one guy there and he was taking orders, preparing the food AND handling cash.  I just got a weird vibe from the place in general.

The workers here are so awesome and know how to have fun!! 

I ordered the chicken shawarma salad. The chicken itself was very lukewarm but the flavors were so amazing I wished it was at least warm in temperature. It was very hard and borderline cold and felt like I was eating leftovers. The salad itself on the other hand was a huge mistake. It was like a grocery store salad thrown in with soggy chick peas and sweet pickles which are super gross. Next time I will opt for a pita or plate instead.

The prices were pretty standard for Mediterranean food but I can go to Paymons for better quality. 12$ for a soggy Luke warm salad...
It's best Mediterranean food you can get in Las Vegas . Its very fresh and the people working overthere are very nice.
This place was very good. I really liked the workers and the food was great. The portions werent enough for me but overall it was a good place.
This place has the best falafel found in Vegas ! Great service, and they even let you sample a falafel. Decent prices and their hummus is definitely up there!

I was impressed with the food. It was great quality. I was not impressed with being charged more than told when ordering. They tell you to sit down, and then they bill you later after you have eaten. The crystal geyser water for 11 cents at Costco is $1.95 a bottle. Pretty crazy. The highlight of this visit was the friendly service. Prepare to be over-charged

"The most expensive falafel in the world." This is the answer my husband received when he called to find out just how much the tasty balls cost here, but the confident owner assured they were also the best. Clearly the owner is an assertive fellow. 

Despite the forecasted price tag, we went, and on our first trip, he encouraged us to share a sampler platter. Well, actually he wanted us to get 2 platters, and 2 came to our table even though we only wanted 1. The whole ordeal was a little uncomfortable and overshadowed the food. Honestly, we left feeling like we had simply eaten the most expensive falafel in the world, and we didn't return for quite some time.

However, they have recently been advertising a $6.99 falafel pita and soda special, and being a a falafal fanatic, I was open for a return visit. The assertive owner was still there, but he was more concerned with another table of guests. He is simply a very proud man, I think, which seems to result in quality offerings, but I could see where he might overpower timid peeps. Chat with him about the food, though, and you will see he is passionate.

On to the food: pickles for your pita!! I always celebrate this little delight, as I think that pickles and falafel are as smart a combo as Wonder Woman and her invisible plane. They have a plentiful topping bar and some hot sauce that will kick your tASStesbuds. Seriously, it's hot. Those accoutrement earn bonus stars, as does the fluffy, soft pita. Additional bonus for the million falafel they stuff into that pita! Okay, so maybe it is not a million, but it was at least 6, which is generous in the land of pockets.

The falafel themselves taste good, but I was surprised that there were no visible spices. I am used to seeing bright green parsley or other spices, but these were a uniform golden color throughout. They were still tasty, and with the pita special running, they are no longer the most expensive falafel in the world. They are now a must try in Vegas! It is all about the special. I hope it sticks around.
The food is alright, but a little pricey, and it wasn't as inviting as I'd like. Let's put it this way...I haven't gone back since, but think it's a fine place...

Over priced and no flavor in anything that I ordered. Once you step in the door they swarm you and pressure you to order. I spent 50$ for lunch! 2 chicken plates and side of hummus! One of the worst places in Vegas! By far...
Paid nearly $17 for a chicken shawarma plate. I have had better, customer service was average at best. If i go next time will try another menu item.

Ordered Sababas through Grubhub while my stylist and i were waiting for my hair to set on Monday, the food arrived and it was Okay..... Not what i was used to when i would eat here all the time. I ordered the Sababa special and honestly i was left disappointed. The chicken rotti was so dry and the two kebabs looked horrible and were beyond dry. The hummus was good the salad was fine, and the Pita bread was very very fresh! Thank you for that!, now off to the Falafel which WAS my favorite part about this place was left in the fryer maybe a minute too long. I was very disappointed considering i was boasting about this place to my stylist, she seemed to have enjoyed her food which was just grilled chicken breast hummus and salad you cant really go wrong with that simple of an order. 44.50 later i will definitely not be ordering from here again.

Items Selected: 
Babaganoush - Open fire cooked Eggplant, Tahini, Garlic, Lemon Juice served with Pita
Hummus with Shawarma - Chicken Rotti, Parsley and Tahini with Pita and Pickles
Falafel Pita - Chickpea Fritters, Pickles, Tahini, Hummus, Mediterranean Salad

Located within walking distance of home it was largely a matter of conflicting schedules that had prevented a visit to Sababa Mediterranean Grill in the past, ownership's observance of Shabbat seeing the space on the corner of Durango and Desert Inn closed from Friday at 3pm until Sunday at eleven o'clock, a relatively light schedule on this particular Friday creating an opportunity to visit a space that has apparently changed ownership several times over the course of its ten year existence.

Presumably a family run space not dissimilar to the likes of Amena and other Mediterranean spots in town, the strong smell of disinfectant prevalent on entry just past 11:30am with no other patrons present and a man who spoke to colleagues in his native tongue seated watching television, it was with curt "hello, what can I get you" that he stood and returned to the counter when a digital menu paraded options slowly, a laminated card with several items crossed off in Sharpie later provided to help better clarify the choices.

Said to be a 100% Kosher space, a warning on the window about bringing in outside food and beverages stressing this while the man in charge also abruptly asked "why you take pictures?" like such a thing were not commonplace or as  if he had something to hide, it was with culturally appropriate music playing and Roku idle screens on television that a three part order was placed, the Pita taken from a Styrofoam cooler and briefly warmed before being placed in foil and presented to the table alongside Babaganoush that was thin yet fragrant with Garlic and Herbs plus plenty of Lemon Juice.

Not particularly in love with the Pita Bread, no evidence of it being homemade in terms of the presentation or fluffiness, it was with another round presented similar to the last that the man brought forth an enormous plate of Hummus topped in marinated Chicken cooked for several minutes on the flattop and drizzled with Tahini, the Bird itself juicy and lean with the plenty of Cumin and Garlic flavor while the Hummus was thick and creamy with enough there to share amongst a party of two or more.

Enjoying two plates of Pickles with the Shawarma, though an unexpected segment of Lemon amidst Carrots and Cabbage was a bit assaulting in one bite, it was with the tab paid and a Sandwich taken for later that the man softened his comment on photographs stating he saw someone else doing it the day prior and wondered why, the sloppy presentation of a Falafel Pita perhaps one reason he may not want people Instagramming his food though the Chickpea Fritters were quite flavorful and relatively low in heft compared to most which prevented them from overwhelming the Lettuce, Tomatoes, Pickles, Dressing and Cucumbers.

THREE STARS:  Although hospitality could use a little work and cleaning of windows should probably be relegated to the hours between closing on Friday and sundown, Sababa provides good value on the dollar in an ever competitive Mediterranean market, the fact that the restaurant keeps 100% Kosher likely of relevance to many as well.

Falafel pita sandwich special, please and thank you. Moist falafel, pita that manages to be both fluffy thick and thin, tasty tahini. This sandwich is so big I have to use a fork.


And don't skip the spicy sauce! Yum!

Lately I've been eating here about once a week, so not sure why I have yet to review this place. I have a bestie that is a vegetarian. She convinced me to try falafel for the first time and I love it here! It's always fresh because you can watch them cook it after you order. The hot sauce on the falafel pita is amazing! It's quite hot so be careful. The crunchy pickles and veggies also add the perfect punch to the savory pita. The $6.95 falafel pita +soda is such a deal for lunch.
Schwarma and hummus are delicious, pita is superb. Chicken curry was ok, nothing special. Good value for what you get.

Disgusted. This place went downhill. Omg my stomach is in pain because of how greasy the falafel was. I could literally taste the grease it was so nasty! I saw a woman walk out of there due to the rude service. Man how I wish I would've followed so my stomach wouldn't be in so much pain right now. Whoever she was I wish I could tell her how lucky she is to have escaped that meal. My chest hurts, my stomach hurts. Ugh!
The best Mediterranean food I've had I'm Vegas. The falafel is the bees knees; it's so moist. Their hummus is amazing too. I also love the friendly staff.

I actually like the food here. But it is ridiculously expensive for what you get. A handful of salad, a small scoop of houmus, and 5 falafels. Probably cost $1 to make and it was $14 including a soft drink. The owner  made a loud comment about how if everyone ate as much as I did he wouldn't have to wash dishes. I was starving. But, regardless it was also said very rude. I was quite offended. Then when paying on the way out, the cook was at the register without gloves handling money. And he rudely announced what I had was called the Hoo-mus falafel plate. Not hummus. I have always call it hummus. After the owners remark and the cook money handling. I won't be back.  Also, my daughter won't go in, because they wouldn't let her feed her infant baby a package of organic veggies. There were 3 adults eating but they said because it's kosher no way.

First time here and with a Groupon. We don't keep kosher but like to support restaurants that do. There are new owners and very friendly staff. The menu was different than we expected after looking on Yelp. There is no longer a lunch special. But frankly, we didn't care. The food was very well spiced and delicious. We ordered one shawarma bowl and one Sababa Mixed Grill special for three people and still had leftovers to take home. The shawarma was moist and fresh. The falafel was the best I have tasted in years. The sides were all delicious. We will definitely come back.
After long time I came again to this place, the new owner doing a great job with the food quality and excellent customer service. It's was good experience and for sure I be back again.

If I could give it a -10 I would! My husband and I were there on Friday and he had the chicken kabob bowl and I had the hummus and eggplant. Eggplant was old and greasy and hummus was old. Now they are kosher and we have been there when the previous owner was there. My husband got violently sick on the chicken so much so I took him to the doctors and doc said it was an extreme case of food poisoning from the chicken. It has been five days now and he is still not feeling well. He did get some meds for nausea and other things that is going on due to food poisoning. The place feels dirty and food is not at fresh as the previous owner had it. Just saying STAY AWAY!

Did they change their falafel recipe here?  I think they did.  I just had lunch here and it was really "meh".  $16 for a shawarma (which after cutting the off the spit still needed to be grilled for an additional 5 minutes) and falafel platter.  Pita was really tough too.  Forget it.  I'm done.  Guess its time to check out Mad Pita!

I'm reviewing the falafel. Best in town, full stop. I tried them almost everywhere and none beats Sababa. Warm fluffy bread, crispy and perfect chickpeas, jam packed with fresh veggies and hummus. You've gotta try it, just remember they're closed on Saturdays for sabbath.

Did a search for Turkish food in yelp and the various places that I ran across did not sound right, this place did. Sadly, it was not turkish food.

There were also no hot servers, matter of fact, there were no women.. all guys... smallish kind of place, clean... felt family run, of your family was all guys. Definite weird kind of "I've got a deal for you" vibe once I walked in.

How is a beef shish kebob platter like $24, but the one size down version is $14? I mean a $10 difference means I better be getting some really hot chick to deliver it to me, or at the very least put something on the plate worth $10 extra dollars.

The food was good, but I think it was more of a kosher food place than a middle eastern place, which I know is difficult to identify, but it was definitely not a place that I would have found myself in unless I was looking for something like that. I was under the impression that it was something else, but I did not come out of the experience scarred or hateful, rather, I am probably not going to go back because of the prices.

I ordered the chicken schwarma, hummus, falafel & salad plate. The chicken schwarma was tender and had a good flavor. Hummus was okay and the falafel was a bit too salty. I paid $18 for this dinner which I think is way over priced for what it is. 

I'm also questioning the handling of the food. The cashier picked up my falafel with his bare hands and threw it in my to-go box ..
Overpriced and bland.  Spent over $45 for 2 people for fast food.  Never going back.
They have gotten much better since my first visit. I've had the falafel (good, fresh), the shawarma  (dolid), and the shakshuka, which they do a very nice job with. Service is also friendly.

My friends and I drove 20 minutes to get lunch here. Online they advertised a $6 special. When we got there they guy in the front told us that they took the promo down. We showed it to him online and they said they wouldn't honor it. So the 6 of us decided to walk out. They were so rude and didn't care that we drove out of the way to come try their food. DO NOT GO THERE...so disrespectful.
Chicken shawarma salad and falafel pita are my go to items here. Fresh ingredients, healthy, good service... Can't ask for much more!

Food is always good. Place is always clean. The owner comes around checks on you and even cleared my table. I had the Chicken Shawarma on pita bread. Delicious! They also have great desserts here too.

If you're looking for fresh Mediterranean food, this is the place! 

Located on the corner of Durango and Flamingo, it's pretty centrally located. They have a beer and wine menu which I thought was funny because it's a very casual "lunch-time" vibe. 

I order the falafel balls and hummus with a side salad because it's filling and only about $10. The food is ready almost immediately and you can be on your way!

Great falafel, salads, shwarma
A Big Yums up!
Great service! According to my husband who had the hummus and falafel he said it's the best in town, I had chicken skewers which were flavorful and the rice and pita were amazing!

Been wanting to try this place out since it's close to work so I bought a $25 groupon for $15.  Called to place my order as I was across the street at Desert Breeze park on my lunch break.  No answer after two attempts. I drive over there and asked the cashier if they take phone orders, she said yes.  I told her I called twice in the last few minutes but no one picked up.  She starts looking around for the phone but couldn't find it.  Not a good start.  I ordered chicken curry and a chicken Rotti Pita sandwich.  She says they are out chicken curry.  I'm surprised and laugh.  She said the owner is the only one who knows the recipe and he probably won't be back until next week.  So no chicken curry for the next week or so.  Jokingly, I asked what else are you out of.  She starts naming off a few items on the menu.  I laugh again. But now, it's not so funny. I just look at her and shake my head, mumbled a few words of criticism and walked out.  I will try again before the groupon expires in couple months. Right now, I wish I never bought it.  The cashier still didn't know where the phone was when I left.  This place is a joke!

Horrible service! Not friendly. Website advertises a $6 lunch special Mon-Fri worker said that they don't have it any more and would not honor it. We drove 20mins out of our way just to try this place. Disappointing, wholesome food with unhealthy attitudes!
Omg everything was delicious!, the guy in the counter was very friendly, I think he is the owner but I'm not sure. I will surely be back!, their burger is soo good!
